title: Versatile VR experience
reviews: The Quest 2 is a well designed VR headset that has the versatility to work as standalone, or connected to a PC for a wider choice of games (if the pc is up to it!). The choice of games is good and growing all the time, just search the Oculus store and you can have a look before purchasing. Don't expect cutting edge visuals in standalone mode, its essentially mobile phone hardware powering the displays. But it gives the VR experience at around half the price of some of the other VR technologies, and without having to have a high spec gaming PC. Being standalone its great to travel with, just draw out the play area and you're good to go. It works really well as a "party game", cast the display to a TV and everyone can see whats on the headset getting everyone involved in the fun. I'd recommend an alternative strap such as the elite strap or similar for a more comfortable experience.

title: Best Bang for Your Buck!
reviews: If you are looking to get into the world of VR, this is a great place to start. The setup is spectacularly easy, setup your Wifi and log in with your Facebook account setup a safety zone in the headset which shows you when you are leaving you're chosen safe area and you're good to go. With the ability to connect to a PC/Laptop either through a link cable (£20 ish) or using air link via the Wifi you can play a multitude of games using for example steamVR, But there is plenty of content without the need to even own a PC/Laptop. If you wear glasses, not an issue the Quest 2 comes with a spacer to help but, I have found I don't need this and my glasses don't touch the lenses in the headset (which could scratch the lenses in the headset). The headset is fairly comfortable to wear however you do need to fiddle to get the lenses in the "sweet spot" otherwise you get a blurry view, however once you figure it out it is easy to get the correct position within a few seconds of putting it on. There are apps for experiencining 3D movies, full 360 degree events like a music concerts, educational films, museums, historic sites, an ISS tour or even a space walk and genuinely tons more. Google Earth VR is fantastic. All in all I love the quest 2 and have no hesitation in recommending it to others looking to get into VR, at this price point it truly is great value for money, And at no point have I been dissapointed.

title: Great VR experience
reviews: Have waited a long time for this and I'm glad I finally got it. There's a great, but small, range of games, fitness, and lots of free entertainment (and paid for - eg films or concerts). Beat Saber, for example, is even better without having to worry about pulling out or stepping on the cable (I have a PSVR). Check out some of the FB groups and get a referral code for store credit - enough for Beat Saber to be free right now. It's also great to be able to play in different places (I've read about people using it while travelling or in their hotel) - I've also watched some YouTube VR and tried the Space Station experience while lying in bed. I recommend trying Bigscreen - you can watch things in your own virtual cinema (you can choose different types of location and your spot in front of the screen) by yourself, or with friends. You can also attend shows and concerts if you pay extra. Fitness is one of the main reasons I got this - boxing games, sport and gym games, music games .. and the distraction of the game really helps keep you going. However, there are some negatives - the headset isn't comfortable straight out of the box. You really need to get a different strap or attachment- check out reviews on YouTube to help you decide. There are better foam attachments for the part that touches your face, and grips for the controllers because the surface is too smooth. It's annoying that you can need so many extras, but you should get them, it's worth the extra money. Also, you can easily use it without a PC, but this also means you're missing out on a much bigger range of games and better graphics - eg the latest Half Life game. Overall, it's a great introduction to VR, in many ways it's much better than the PSVR and there are some amazing experiences waiting for you. But make sure you check out some of the YT reviews to help you get the most out of it.

title: Oculus Quest 2
reviews: Design: The headset looks sleek and well designed. I would recommend fitting the provided glasses spacer and silicone cover before even using the headset, which improves comfort considerably. If you are not used to wearing a headset, the weight on your head can feel uncomfortable initially, but it is not a deal-breaker as this is something that you get used to over time. One thing to note, there are only 3 lens settings for IPD (distance between eyes). However, these 3 options should accommodate most people. Battery life: Roughly 2.5 hours from a full charge, which, if you think about it, is pretty good considering it is a standalone product and is not wired to anything. However, it does charge quickly with the provided charger, which is good. If you want to use it for extended periods, make sure you have a long USB-C cable and plug it into the mains as the one provided is very short (keep in mind, the headset may get warm during extended use.) Connectivity: Simple as can be, turn the headset on and away you go. I recommend Oculus Link (or Air Link, which is even better if you have the internet speed for it!) if you have a gaming PC alongside the headset. Oculus/Air Link will enable you to play SteamVR titles such as Half-Life: Alyx etc., which wouldn't be otherwise available on the Quest 2. Ease of use: Impossibly easy setup and general use, but you require a FaceBook account, which isn't ideal. Also, you will need money aside to buy games/applications, so keep that in mind - there are some free applications, but for fully-fledged experiences, you'll most likely need some extra money. In conclusion, I would recommend the Quest 2 to people looking for an introduction to VR and people who have experienced VR in the past. For the price, nothing in the market can currently beat it.

reviews: I was wary at first because tech reviews on YouTube said the basic strap is uncomfortable but honestly I find it absolutely fine. If you're someone who isn't always home and has children then it's well worth it as it's easy to carry around, though I do recommend getting silicone covers for the controllers and especially protection for the lenses, as the cost of fixing the lenses is so high you may as well buy a whole new headset. The best thing about the Oculus is the safety features, you create the boundaries around your living room and it will warn you if you're stepping outside of them. Once you step outside them you can see everything around you. It can break immersion in games at times but it's a still a feature best to have. It does have 2 hour battery life which can be extended by getting an external battery, but especially for children I think 2 hours is enough. I have been told its best not to plug it into the mains to play it as it can potentially damage it.

title: Great headset, shame about the strap
reviews: I've had this headset for a few weeks now, it was easy to set up - brand new condition - and much more lightweight in comparison to the Quest 1. (If using a Link cable) it also holds charge for a good few hours. Getting set up to play via the PC was a bit of a hasstle but once it has been it's now a very straightforward process. When in-game, the Oculus app is okay to use, not the best but it's easy to figure out. Sometimes the loading screens between games/steam/virtual desktop can lag/jitter, this is something to get use to. The main downside to this product is the strap quality. It's awful and very uncomfortable. I had to buy an alternative strap to make this wearable. For the price, I would have expected a much better quality strap to come with the product. The face visors are also not the best. The sponge one causes skin burn and soaks up sweat making it very unhygienic. The silicon one although easier to clean is very hard and does cause some strain. Again, I would reccomend buying a soft padded face visor for this item. I've done this and it makes wearing time much more pleasent! If purchasing for a young person/child, due to weight and comfort I highly recommend buying a better (weighted) head strap and face visor. Overall, it's a very good product, much better than the Quest 1, great charging hold, and lost of great games to enjoy!
